edu.nps.moves.gateway

Class ConnectionManager

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.nps.moves.gateway.ConnectionManager
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable

    public class ConnectionManager
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Runnable
    Manages the various connections established by web pages. There may be N web pages connected to the gateway. This manages the connections established by the web pages and provides a central point for sending messages to all connected pages.

    We need to be careful about concurrency here--things are happening async and we can be multithreaded. This is a singleton.

    This is also multi-threaded. It turns out that when a packet is received from a client, it's a bad idea to repeat that packet out to all connections in the same thread. It takes a long time, and the WebPageConnection object can't receive more packets while the data is being distributed out to all the other connections (which, remember, takes a long time.) Instead, as soon as an incoming message is received from a client, it's placed into a FIFO queue (with concurrency protection) in this class. The logic in the onBinaryMessage can immediately return, and the logic in this thread can retrieve the message from the queue and distribute it to the other participants. Since almost everything, even phones, have multi-core CPUs these days this can happen in parallel.

    The method that retrieves the next message from the queue will block if there are no messages in the queue.

      • connectionManager

        public static ConnectionManager connectionManager
        Singleton

      • connections

        public java.util.concurrent.ConcurrentMap<DISEndpoint,DISEndpoint> connections
        Every connection established by a web page is kept in this list. This should be a concurrentHashSet, but there doesn't seem to be one out of the box.

      • distributionThread

        public static java.lang.Thread distributionThread
        Thread responsible for repeating an incoming binary message out to all clients

      • binaryMessageQueue

        public java.util.concurrent.LinkedBlockingQueue<ConnectionManager.BinaryMessageAndSender> binaryMessageQueue
        FIFO queue. The receiving connection places it into this queue, and the distribution thread retrieves it, and repeats it out to all clients.

      • addConnection

        public void addConnection(DISEndpoint aConnection)
        Add a client connection to the list. Messages will be relayed to this client.

      • removeConnection

        public void removeConnection(DISEndpoint aConnection)
        Remove a connection from the list of active connections. This is typically called when a client closes the connection. We remove it from the list of active connections.
        Parameters:
        aConnection -

      • repeatMessage

        public void repeatMessage(java.lang.String message,
                          DISEndpoint sender)
        Send a message we have received from the sender out to all the other clients, but do NOT send it back to the client that sent it. Typically the message is in string JSON format.
        Parameters:
        message - message received from sender
        sender - the client that sent the message. The message is not sent to this client. If the sender is null, the message is sent to all connected clients.

      • repeatBinaryMessage

        public void repeatBinaryMessage(byte[] data,
                                DISEndpoint sender)
        Send a binary message we have received from the sender out to all the other clients, but do NOT send it back to the client that sent it. The message is typically in IEEE DIS binary format.
        Parameters:
        data - message received from sender
        sender - the client that sent the message. The message is not sent to this client. If the sender is null, the message is sent to all clients.

      • enqueueBinaryMessage

        public void enqueueBinaryMessage(byte[] data,
                                 DISEndpoint sender)
        A web socket (or native DIS network reader) has received a message, and wants to distribute it to clients. It is placed into a FIFO queue, which has concurrency protection, and the run() thread retrieves the message and distributes it. This is better because almost all CPUs are multicore these days and it runs in true parallel fashion.
        Parameters:
        data -
        sender -

      • getNextMessage

        public ConnectionManager.BinaryMessageAndSender getNextMessage()

      • run

        public void run()
        This method retrieves messages from the FIFO queue and repeats them to other clients. It will block if there are no messages to get.
        Specified by:
        run in interface java.lang.Runnable
